segments.text: So after 1,158 hours in cloud code here's the thing nobody tells you Most of what you'll find on YouTube
about this too already is outdated The system changes every few months The workflow shift on work in October generally
does not work in February And I'm not talking about small stuff I'm talking about fundamentally different ways of working
I spend those hours building 3 production systems a SaaS that does 100 grand a year A government access control
system and a full business running through AI agents and custom service NTPs This is everything that actually matters And
there's one thing everyone recommends that made everything worse for me I'll get to that So let's start from the
beginning My first project was the MChamp It's an AI sales agent You connect it to WhatsApp Instagram your website
whatever and it handles customer conversations Closes
deals makes about 100 grand a year in revenue Now the M-CHAMP already existed when I started using Cloud Code
existing code base And honestly the code was kind of a mess because it was originally built with a no-code
tool called FlutterFlow And then we exported it and the setup was just you open the repo and run Cloud
Code It goes through everything reads the files and understands the structure That's it We— there was no major migration
no restructuring
With just the initial— initialization command and go Did it break stuff Yeah but so do normal developers That's not
a cloud code problem And with the latest models it barely makes mistakes anymore But here's where it gets interesting
On top of the MChamp I built a separate system with 6 AI agents that handle the entire support pipeline
If a bug comes in one agent figures out what's wrong another one writes the fix Another one messages the
customer on WhatsApp saying it's resolved I wake up check the fix approve it done 6 agents 4 custom MCPs
all running in production And the setup file for this project is just a basic cloud.md
file explaining the repo and how to add new agents Nothing fancy When you're starting out you don't need a
complex setup You just need to start Now here's where most people go wrong and I made this exact mistake
So once the MChamp was running I started working on a much bigger project a government access control system
You know tap to enter badges admin dashboard mobile app the whole thing It's over 8,000 files And I thought
well cloud code is amazing right So let me just let it build everything fully autonomous end to end and
no human is checking anything
Well it does not work And I know that's not what you want to hear because everyone on the internet
is telling you to just let AI do everything but for anything going into production the bottleneck is checking whether
the code actually works Class can write tests but they're basic and testing the actual interface What takes just— takes
you just a minute just clicking around and seeing if things look right takes the AI 50 minutes It has
to open a browser take screenshots analyze them It doesn't have that visual speed yet So the real workflow is
AI builds fast human verifies That's it Don't skip the verify step I tried it it cost me weeks but
that wasn't even the real lesson from this project The real lesson was something I stumbled into by accident So
I'm working on this government project 27 features across the app and Claude keeps losing context It doesn't know what
a feature is supposed to do It's mixing things up writing code that runs but doesn't fit the system And
I'm thinking okay the model isn't stupid anymore They're really really smart now I've seen what they can do So
the problem has to be on my end So I reorganize everything one folder per feature Authentication gets its own
folder Access badges gets their own folder Permission locations cards every feature isolated including the util functions for that feature
in the features folder 15 features on the backend 12 on the frontend
each one self-contained
But here's the part that made a real difference Every single feature folder gets its its own instruction file not
just a description I'm talking about what the feature is for how it works what the current status is everything
Claude needs to understand the context 27 of these across the whole project So when Claude works on the access
badge feature it automatically knows all of that context It knows what the feature is for how it connects to
the rest of the system what's already been built That was the unlock Claude is only as good as the
context you give it No context it write code that runs but makes no sense The other thing is I
did project management inside the repo not Jira not Linear just text files 107 task files to do in progress
completed block dependencies between tasks So why not a real project management tool Because cloud code can read local files
instantly The moment you make it talk to an external tool through an API it's slower and less reliable We
actually built the custom integration with ClickUp and it's still slower than just reading a text text file for an
AI Local is king when it comes to Cloud Code So at this point I've got a SaaS running on
Cloud Code a government system with a proper structure and I'm thinking okay I figured this out But then things
got a lot bigger Quick thing if you're watching this and you want to set up Cloud Code for a
real project I'm building a community called Cloudify where we do exactly that Real builds not just toy projects Links
in the description So the third project isn't even a project It's my entire business running through cloud code I
own a consulting business this channel a SaaS product and kind delivery all from one repo over 1,000 files 7
custom SAP servers And when I say custom I mean I built this myself or I let cloud build them
for me One checks how brands appear when you ask ChatGPT or Gemini a question One does keyword research One
generates images One finds stock video One scans what's trending on GitHub and Hacker News for content ideas So why
did I build my own Because once other people have made— don't quite do what you exactly need for real
work Every time I hit that wall I ended up building my own That's a pattern And of course you
can use that existing MCP as a base because most MCPs are open source anyway Now here's a big one
and this goes against what basically everyone is saying right now Everyone talks about giving agent roles make a frontend
developer agent a PM agent a designer agent The Governed Project actually has 50 agents set up like this And
if I'm being honest it doesn't make things notice— noticeably better They work they run but the output isn't really
different from just using Cloud Code directly with good context What actually makes a difference is giving agent-specific tasks For
example not be a developer but instead it's take this transcript and generate a video timeline or take this data
and create a client report or find the best GIFs for each section of this video Each agent gets specific
tools and specific context They do one thing well 14 of these plus 24 skills A skill is basically a
set of instructions for a specific job So instead of explaining how to write a video script every time Cloud
just loads the skill and knows exactly what to do Same for audits reports timelines one skill per job And
the latest evolution is these task agents working together in teams Not one agent calling another actual teams with a
shared task list So I have a command it says produce this video it kicks off a team One agent
builds a timeline another one finds GIFs another one sources stock footage They're all working in parallel off the same
task list coordinating with each other That's a part that feels genuinely new I'm not managing each agent They pick
up task do their work report back It's the closest thing to having an actual team And you might be
wondering when do you use a sub-agent
versus a full team It's quite simple A sub-agent is for one-off tasks
You send it off does the thing it's done The context is gone A team is when you need back
and forth multiple agents coordinating
Passing workgroups between each other building on what the others did That's the difference And here's something nobody talks about
Just like your code accumulates technical debt your cloud code setup does too Skills get outdated Agents reference old patterns
instructions They start contradicting each other He wrote something 3 months ago that's now wrong and the AI is following
those old instructions instead of the new ones I have a 346-line document just for how to maintain the AI
setup itself
Every time something gets added I clean up the whole structure same way you'd clean up code And sometimes Claude
creates new shortcuts on its own I noticed a workflow I kept repeating and just made a command for it
without me asking And the last thing the workflow keeps changing When I started you had to approve every single
edit Then I realized you can bypass that Then plan mode came out where Claude plans first and you review
before it builds Now I just say think about this first in plain English and it does and it even
goes into plan mode itself That's 4 different workflows in less than a year If you're watching a cloud code
tutorial from 6 months ago it's probably teaching you the old way All right so remember that one thing I
said at the beginning the one thing everyone recommends that made everything worse It's adding everything at once Every MCP
server you can find every skill every plugin People treat it like a shopping spree more tools more power
Well it's actually the opposite You give Claude 42s and it doesn't know which ones to use Quality goes down
The government project has 15 agents but it didn't start with 15 I started with zero hit the wall added
one hit another wall added another Every single one earned its place Start with nothing Add things only when you
feel the pain of not having them Less is more even though it isn't So that's 1,158 hours compressed You
start by just opening your repo and going Don't overthink it It works on messy code bases It works on
existing projects Then you structure everything one folder per feature context files everywhere task inside the repo and always a
human checking anything that goes to production And eventually you build a system around it Custom MCP servers when the
generic ones don't cut it Task agents instead of raw agents And you maintain that system the same way you
maintain your code The difference between 10 hours in cloud code and 1,000 hours isn't knowing more features is knowing
which ones to ignore If you want to see the actual repo structures agent configs and workflows I use I
share all of that inside Codify Links in the description I'll see you in the next one Bye

text: So after 1,158 hours in cloud code, here's the thing nobody tells you. Most of what you'll find on YouTube about this too already is outdated. The system changes every few months. The workflow shift on work in October generally does not work in February. And I'm not talking about small stuff. I'm talking about fundamentally different ways of working. I spend those hours building 3 production systems, a SaaS that does 100 grand a year. A government access control system, and a full business running through AI agents and custom service NTPs. This is everything that actually matters. And there's one thing everyone recommends that made everything worse for me. I'll get to that. So let's start from the beginning. My first project was the MChamp. It's an AI sales agent. You connect it to WhatsApp, Instagram, your website, whatever, and it handles customer conversations. Closes deals, makes about 100 grand a year in revenue. Now the M-CHAMP already existed when I started using Cloud Code, existing code base. And honestly, the code was kind of a mess because it was originally built with a no-code tool called FlutterFlow. And then we exported it and the setup was just, you open the repo and run Cloud Code. It goes through everything, reads the files and understands the structure. That's it. We— there was no major migration, no restructuring. With just the initial— initialization command and go. Did it break stuff? Yeah, but so do normal developers. That's not a cloud code problem. And with the latest models, it barely makes mistakes anymore. But here's where it gets interesting. On top of the MChamp, I built a separate system with 6 AI agents that handle the entire support pipeline. If a bug comes in, one agent figures out what's wrong, another one writes the fix. Another one messages the customer on WhatsApp saying it's resolved. I wake up, check the fix, approve it, done. 6 agents, 4 custom MCPs, all running in production. And the setup file for this project is just a basic cloud.md file explaining the repo and how to add new agents. Nothing fancy. When you're starting out, you don't need a complex setup. You just need to start. Now here's where most people go wrong, and I made this exact mistake. So once the MChamp was running, I started working on a much bigger project, a government access control system. You know, tap to enter badges, admin dashboard, mobile app, the whole thing. It's over 8,000 files. And I thought, well, cloud code is amazing, right? So let me just let it build everything fully autonomous, end to end, and no human is checking anything. Well, it does not work. And I know that's not what you want to hear because everyone on the internet is telling you to just let AI do everything, but for anything going into production, the bottleneck is checking whether the code actually works. Class can write tests, but they're basic and testing the actual interface. What takes just— takes you just a minute, just clicking around and seeing if things look right, takes the AI 50 minutes. It has to open a browser, take screenshots, analyze them. It doesn't have that visual speed yet. So the real workflow is AI builds fast, human verifies. That's it. Don't skip the verify step. I tried it, it cost me weeks, but that wasn't even the real lesson from this project. The real lesson was something I stumbled into by accident. So I'm working on this government project, 27 features across the app, and Claude keeps losing context. It doesn't know what a feature is supposed to do. It's mixing things up, writing code that runs but doesn't fit the system. And I'm thinking, okay, the model isn't stupid anymore. They're really, really smart now. I've seen what they can do. So the problem has to be on my end. So I reorganize everything, one folder per feature. Authentication gets its own folder. Access badges gets their own folder. Permission, locations, cards, every feature isolated, including the util functions for that feature in the features folder. 15 features on the backend, 12 on the frontend, each one self-contained. But here's the part that made a real difference. Every single feature folder gets its, its own instruction file, not just a description. I'm talking about what the feature is for, how it works, what the current status is, everything Claude needs to understand the context. 27 of these across the whole project. So when Claude works on the access badge feature, it automatically knows all of that context. It knows what the feature is for, how it connects to the rest of the system, what's already been built. That was the unlock. Claude is only as good as the context you give it. No context, it write code that runs but makes no sense. The other thing is I did project management inside the repo, not Jira, not Linear, just text files, 107 task files to do, in progress, completed, block dependencies between tasks. So why not a real project management tool? Because cloud code can read local files instantly. The moment you make it talk to an external tool through an API it's slower and less reliable. We actually built the custom integration with ClickUp and it's still slower than just reading a text, text file for an AI. Local is king when it comes to Cloud Code. So at this point I've got a SaaS running on Cloud Code, a government system with a proper structure, and I'm thinking, okay, I figured this out. But then things got a lot bigger. Quick thing, if you're watching this and you want to set up Cloud Code for a real project, I'm building a community called Cloudify where we do exactly that. Real builds, not just toy projects. Links in the description. So the third project isn't even a project. It's my entire business running through cloud code. I own a consulting business, this channel, a SaaS product, and kind delivery, all from one repo, over 1,000 files, 7 custom SAP servers. And when I say custom, I mean I built this myself or I let cloud build them for me. One checks how brands appear when you ask ChatGPT or Gemini a question. One does keyword research. One generates images. One finds stock video. One scans what's trending on GitHub and Hacker News for content ideas. So why did I build my own? Because once other people have made— don't quite do what you exactly need for real work. Every time I hit that wall, I ended up building my own. That's a pattern. And of course you can use that existing MCP as a base because most MCPs are open source anyway. Now here's a big one, and this goes against what basically everyone is saying right now. Everyone talks about giving agent roles, make a frontend developer agent, a PM agent, a designer agent. The Governed Project actually has 50 agents set up like this. And if I'm being honest, it doesn't make things notice— noticeably better. They work, they run, but the output isn't really different from just using Cloud Code directly with good context. What actually makes a difference is giving agent-specific tasks. For example, not be a developer, but instead it's take this transcript and generate a video timeline, or take this data and create a client report, or find the best GIFs for each section of this video. Each agent gets specific tools and specific context. They do one thing well. 14 of these plus 24 skills. A skill is basically a set of instructions for a specific job. So instead of explaining how to write a video script every time Cloud just loads the skill and knows exactly what to do. Same for audits, reports, timelines, one skill per job. And the latest evolution is these task agents working together in teams. Not one agent calling another, actual teams with a shared task list. So I have a command, it says produce this video, it kicks off a team. One agent builds a timeline, another one finds GIFs, another one sources stock footage. They're all working in parallel off the same task list, coordinating with each other. That's a part that feels genuinely new. I'm not managing each agent. They pick up task, do their work, report back. It's the closest thing to having an actual team. And you might be wondering, when do you use a sub-agent versus a full team? It's quite simple. A sub-agent is for one-off tasks. You send it off, does the thing, it's done. The context is gone. A team is when you need back and forth, multiple agents coordinating. Passing workgroups between each other, building on what the others did. That's the difference. And here's something nobody talks about. Just like your code accumulates technical debt, your cloud code setup does too. Skills get outdated. Agents reference old patterns, instructions. They start contradicting each other. He wrote something 3 months ago that's now wrong, and the AI is following those old instructions instead of the new ones. I have a 346-line document just for how to maintain the AI setup itself. Every time something gets added, I clean up the whole structure, same way you'd clean up code. And sometimes Claude creates new shortcuts on its own. I noticed a workflow I kept repeating and just made a command for it without me asking. And the last thing, the workflow keeps changing. When I started, you had to approve every single edit. Then I realized you can bypass that. Then plan mode came out where Claude plans first and you review before it builds. Now I just say, think about this first in plain English, and it does, and it even goes into plan mode itself. That's 4 different workflows in less than a year. If you're watching a cloud code tutorial from 6 months ago, it's probably teaching you the old way. All right, so remember that one thing I said at the beginning, the one thing everyone recommends that made everything worse? It's adding everything at once. Every MCP server you can find, every skill, every plugin. People treat it like a shopping spree, more tools, more power. Well, it's actually the opposite. You give Claude 42s and it doesn't know which ones to use. Quality goes down. The government project has 15 agents, but it didn't start with 15. I started with zero, hit the wall, added one, hit another wall, added another. Every single one earned its place. Start with nothing. Add things only when you feel the pain of not having them. Less is more, even though it isn't. So that's 1,158 hours compressed. You start by just opening your repo and going. Don't overthink it. It works on messy code bases. It works on existing projects. Then you structure everything, one folder per feature, context files everywhere, task inside the repo, and always a human checking anything that goes to production. And eventually you build a system around it. Custom MCP servers when the generic ones don't cut it. Task agents instead of raw agents. And you maintain that system the same way you maintain your code. The difference between 10 hours in cloud code and 1,000 hours isn't knowing more features, is knowing which ones to ignore. If you want to see the actual repo structures, agent configs, and workflows I use, I share all of that inside Codify. Links in the description. I'll see you in the next one. Bye.
